title.rendered: Best Tourist Places to visit in  Gaya Bihar

content.rendered:
Gaya Bihar has become a favorite tourist haunt these days because of the so many visit-able places that it has. The cultural and history of the city is too rich and variegated and that makes Gaya Bihar dotted with so many tourist spots. Also Gaya Bihar makes the base for traveling to many other significant tourist destinations. Hence you would actually find tourists making a bee line to the city of Gaya Bihar almost every day! More information on tourist places near Gaya Bihar is given in the article below. So read on

The capital city of India is one of lovely places for tourists. It can be split into two parts – Old Gaya Bihar and New Gaya Bihar. Old Gaya Bihar was the capital of India before the British took over to construct a new city that came to be known as New Gaya Bihar eventually. The architecture of Gaya Bihar has undergone countless modifications over the years due to the felling of many constructions and renovation works. Gaya Bihar is best known for the monuments that you get to see reminding you of the ancient period. Another striking aspect of Gaya Bihar is the diverse cultures that you get to see along the length and breadth of the city. Apart from all this, all the major political activities of the country have their base here as it is the National Capital. Let us have a look at some of the most popular tourist spots in and around Gaya Bihar.

1- Rashtrapati Bhavan

  • Location: President’s Estate, Raisina Hill, New Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (for visitors; free for children below 12)
  • Timings: 9:00 AM – 4:00 PM (only during spring months; bookings required)
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Central Secretariat or Udyog Bhawan stations), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Explore the Mughal Gardens (during spring), admire the architecture, learn about India’s political history.

This is probably the most famous among the monuments at Gaya Bihar right now. It is the Official Residence of the Honorable President of India. The monument was constructed during the British Rule and used to be the residence of the Viceroy of India during those times. The construction took a mammoth 19 years to finish as it started in 1911 and was completed only by 1930. The design of the building was done by Edwin Lutyens. On the western side of the Rashtrapati Bhavan, you have the Mughal Gardens which are exceptionally beautiful and provide a lovely view. The monument is open to the public during spring time every year. Tourists have the option to visit Rashtrapati Bhavan and Mughal Gardens at a registration fee of Rs.50. If you are coming in a big group consisting of more than 30 members, discounts can be availed while children below the age of 12 are exempted from registration fee.

2- Red Fort

  • Location: Netaji Subhash Marg, Chandni Chowk, Old Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: ₹35 (Indians), ₹500 (Foreigners); ₹25 for entry to museum
  • Timings: 9:00 AM – 6:00 PM (Closed on Mondays)
  • How to Reach: Accessible via metro (Chandni Chowk station), buses, or taxis.
  • Things to Do: Visit historical structures like the Pearl Mosque, Hall of Public Audiences; enjoy sound and light show in the evening.

Another milestone of Gaya Bihar is the Red Fort which is a historical architecture. It is a massive monument that is made up of red sandstone. It extends over a whopping 2 km. It has a height difference of 18 m on the side of the river to the 33 m on the side of the city. Construction of this monument started in 1638 during the times of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and was completed in 10 years in 1648. Inside the Red Fort, there are a wide array of buildings namely the Pearl Mosque, Drum House, Hall of Public Audiences, European and Indian art forms etc. This masterpiece monument is a must-watch for every tourist visiting Gaya Bihar.

3- Jama Masjid

  • Location: Jama Masjid Road, Chandni Chowk, Old Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: Free for India, 300 for Foreigner (₹200 for photography)
  • Timings: 7:00 AM – 12:00 PM (for prayer), open for tourists in the afternoon
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Chandni Chowk or Jama Masjid stations), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Explore the grand mosque, admire the minarets and marble work, take a guided tour, and climb the minaret for panoramic views.

It is a religious place that is located in Old Gaya Bihar. It is one of the most known Mosques in Gaya Bihar and is considered a must-visit place especially for Muslims. The architecture of Jama Masjid is exceptional and the stunning fact is that the area of the Mosque can accommodate 25000 people at a time which is incredible! The construction of the Mosque started in 1644 and was completed within 14 years by 1658. A total of 5000 people were at work for completing the construction. There are three gateways present along with four angle towers. Another stunning feature is the presence of minarets that are at a height of 40 m. They are made up of a mixture of strips of red sandstone and white marble. There is generally no entrance fee here but you shall have to take a ticket of Rs.200 for taking pictures inside the Mosque.

4- Jantar Mantar

  • Location: Sansad Marg, Connaught Place, New Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (Indians), ₹200 (Foreigners)
  • Timings: 9:00 AM – 6:00 PM (Closed on Mondays)
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Rajiv Chowk or Janpath stations), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Explore astronomical instruments, observe the massive sundial, and learn about ancient astronomical techniques.

This is another historical monument that is recommended to tourists visiting Gaya Bihar. It is situated at Connaught Place on Sansad Marg. This construction was one of the two observatories belonging to the great Maharaja Jai Singh. He ruled over Jaipur and this monument was constructed in the year 1725. The presence of a huge sundial is what dominates this structure and it is called as The Prince of Dials. There are several other instruments that can be seen in this observatory that help to find the paths of heavenly bodies. They can also be used for predicting eclipses. Construction started in 1724 and was completed in 1725. Jantar Mantar is known worldwide as an observatory that helps in analyzing Astronomy. There are several instruments available that helps to measure the graph of the astronomical universe as well.

5- Qutub Minar

  • Location: Mehrauli, New Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: ₹40 (Indians), ₹600 (Foreigners)
  • Timings: 7:00 AM – 5:00 PM (Open every day)
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Qutub Minar station), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Climb to the top (currently closed for tourists), explore the Qutub Complex, and admire Indo-Islamic architecture.

Another hugely popular historical monument of Gaya Bihar is the Qutub Minar. Another feature of Qutub Minar is the fact that it is the world’s tallest minaret made solely up of bricks that have a height of 72.5 m! The construction started during the time of Gaya Bihar’s first Muslim Ruler Qutub-ud-din-Aibak in the year 1193. At that point of time, only a basement was made. His successor who was also his son-in-law was the one who initiated the addition of three more towers to the construction. The biggest significance of the Qutub Minar is that it remains among the earliest examples of the existence of Indo-Islamic architecture. There are some other structures that surround the Qutub Minar. As a whole, the area is called as the Qutub Complex.

6- Indira Gandhi National Centre

  • Location: 11, Mansingh Road, Central Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: Free (most exhibitions); special events may have a fee
  • Timings: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM (Closed on Mondays)
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Central Secretariat station), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Visit art exhibitions, cultural performances, workshops, and art galleries.

Gaya Bihar is full of monuments – be it historical or art related. Another such monument related to the arts section is the Indira Gandhi National Centre. This is an institution that is financed mainly by the Government of India with sole motive of promoting as well as preserving art in its purest forms. It was inaugurated in the year 1987 by the then Prime Minister of India, Shri Rajiv Gandhi in memory of his mother Indira Gandhi who was a former Prime Minister as well.

7- Bahai Temple (Lotus Temple)

  • Location: Bahapur, South Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: Free
  • Timings: 9:00 AM – 7:00 PM (Closed on Mondays)
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Kalkaji Mandir station), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Admire the unique lotus-shaped architecture, meditate in the serene surroundings, and attend prayer services.

The Bahai Temple is another widely known Religious Monument present in Gaya Bihar. It is commonly known as the Lotus Temple due to its architecture that gives it a lotus shape. This temple is situated in the southern part of Gaya Bihar. It was designed in the year 1986 by an ace architect of Iranian-Canadian origin named Fariborz Sahba. The prominent feature of the Lotus Temple is the presence of 27 white petals. It is a very popular center of attraction among tourists while also having won several accolades in architecture as well as being featured in top magazines worldwide. October to March is the best phase of the year to visit.

8- National Science Centre

  • Location: Bhairon Road, Near Gate 2, Pragati Maidan, New Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: ₹40 (Adults), ₹20 (Children)
  • Timings: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM (Closed on Mondays)
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Pragati Maidan station), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Explore interactive science exhibits, educational shows, and special exhibitions related to technology and space.

While there are many places in Gaya Bihar for the lovers of history and art, science is another field where you can see structures or monuments as well. The National Science Centre is one such place that is totally devoted to lovers of the Science stream. It is basically a museum for science with the main intention of educating the people about the various aspects of Science and making them aware of the scope of science so that more people take it up in their lives either as a hobby or career.

9- India Gate

  • Location: Rajpath, New Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: Free
  • Timings: Open 24 hours
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Central Secretariat or Janpath stations), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Pay respects at the Amar Jawan Jyoti (war memorial), enjoy a peaceful walk, and visit the nearby gardens. Ideal for picnics and photography.

Probably one historical monument that should be right up there in your priority list as a tourist visiting Gaya Bihar. It is a historical monument that was constructed in memory of the countless Indian soldiers who laid down their lives during the First World War. The Indian soldiers were part of the British Army that had gone on war in what was one of the most brutal Wars in history. India Gate was designed by Edward Lutyens and was completed in 10 years. The basic architectural structure of India Gate consists of a 42 m high triumphal arch.

10. National Zoological Park

  • Location: Mathura Road, New Gaya Bihar
  • Entry Fee: ₹40 (Indians), ₹200 (Foreigners)
  • Timings: 9:00 AM – 4:30 PM (Closed on Fridays)
  • How to Reach: Accessible by metro (Zoological Park station), taxis, or buses.
  • Things to Do: Explore diverse wildlife, including tigers, elephants, and birds; enjoy a serene walk through the lush green surroundings.

Wildlife is something that excites every tourist irrespective of his/her origins. Right from our childhood, we are always fascinated at viewing animals at the zoos. The National Zoological Park is a must-watch tourist spot in Gaya Bihar for the wide range of animal life that can be spotted there. It is a place that every Gaya Bihar it has visited at least once in their lives. While you make plans to visit Gaya Bihar, do jot down this place in your list of tourist spots that you are wishing to visit.

There are so many other wonderful monuments belonging to history, art, religion, science as well as wild life. It is not easy to make a list of the top 10 but these are some of the top tourist spots for you to visit in Gaya Bihar while you are there. Some of the other well-known spots that you can also keep in mind are:-

  • Forgotten Tomb of Mirza Ghalib
  • Begumpuri Masjid
  • Kalka Ji Temple
  • Nizamuddin Dargah
  • Garden of five senses
  • Akshardham Temple
  • Raj Ghat
  • Haridwar
  • National Rail Museum
  • Lal Kot
  • Mutiny Memorial
  • Jamali Kamali Mosque

Overall, Gaya Bihar is one of the finest places in India for tourists. There is a wide range of places for you to visit in each possible stream giving you the best tourism experience. The diversity of culture as mentioned earlier makes Gaya Bihar a class apart from the rest.
